description.narrative: ASSN aims to conduct a brief study on the ability of South Sudan CSOs to play active role in influencing SSR in the context of peace processes and the efforts made to empower them to do so since the outbreak of internal conflict in December 2013. Focusing on the past five years, this includes an analysis of CSO engagements and roles in peace processes and their contributions to peace agreements. The study will also look at how the ASSN and external actors have assisted South Sudan CSOs engagement with SSR processes and the extent to which this support has impacted the ability of CSOs to practically impact SSR provisions of peace agreements. It will contain a detailed analysis of the SSR provisions of peace agreements and how CSOs positioned themselves and influenced political actors, local, national, regional, international, and non-governmental bodies engaged in SSR/G work. The study will describe success stories and persisting challenges when influencing SSR and peace agreements. It will also include recommendations on how civil societycan effectively be supported to play an active role in influencing the implementation of the R-ARCSS and current opportunities for security sector reform.

participating-org.narrative:
The African Security Sector Network (ASSN) was created at Elmina, Ghana, in November 2003 out of a recognition of the need to harmonise and facilitate the activities of the various African organisations working in the area of Security Sector Reform and Governance(SSR/G).
The principal objective of the network is to promote democratically governed and effective security for the peoples of Africa, and to enhance the capacity of African governments, security institutions, legislatures and civil society organizations to undertake and own Security Sector Reform (SSR) programmes and projects.
The ASSN has developed as a multidisciplinary network spanningacademics, think-tanks, CSOs, security practitioners (active and retired), legislators in defence and security committees, etc, with a pan-African character that enables experiences from different traditions of security organisation and practice (Anglophone, Francophone and Lusophone) to be shared.
The network derives its core strength from its diverse competencies and locations (which enable it to work for change from both within and without); from a capacity for internal debate; and an ability to engage a broad range of security actors (national, regional and international), as well as policy-and decision-makers.
